questions.text:
A 72-year-old male is in the cardiac intensive care unit due to decompensated heart failure. He has been undergoing diuretic therapy with a bumetanide intravenous infusion for the past week. The patient’s hospital course has been complicated by Clostridium difficile colitis, and he has had multiple episodes of profuse diarrhea. During rounds, the patient becomes acutely altered. A telemetry monitoring rhythm strip is shown below.  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

Which of the following electrolyte disturbances is the most likely precipitant of these ECG findings?
questions.solution:
The above telemetry strip is consistent with torsades de pointes, or polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. This dangerous arrhythmia is most commonly associated with hypomagnesemia and can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation if the underlying cause is not promptly addressed. This patient has been undergoing loop diuretic therapy with concomitant diarrhea, which likely led to dangerously low magnesium levels.  

Magnesium is a divalent cation that has importance in membrane stability, muscle contraction, metabolism, and neuronal transmission. Hypomagnesima generally occurs due to either gastrointestinal losses or renal losses. Examples of gastrointestinal losses include prolonged malnutrition, diarrhea, malabsorption syndromes, or proton pump inhibitor therapy. Renal losses occur commonly due to diuretic therapy, uncontrolled diabetes, or congenital conditions such as Gitelman syndrome.    

Regardless of the cause, the symptoms of hypomagnesemia are similar and include convulsions, seizures, tetany, and ventricular arrhythmias. Hypomagnesemia may also cause a prolonged QT interval that can degrade into torsades de pointes.   

Option Analysis

✅ Hypomagnesemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypophosphatemia:
Incorrect: Hypophosphatemia is not commonly observed in patients taking loop diuretics. Conditions associated with hypophosphatemia include chronic alcohol use, urinary phosphate-wasting syndromes (e.g. Fanconi syndrome), or chronic ingestion of antacids and phosphate binders.
❌ Hypocalcemia :
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia can cause a prolonged QT interval and degrade into torsades de pointes. However, it is a much rarer cause than hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia. 
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Diuretics and dehydration from infectious colitis can precipitate hyponatremia; however, acute hyponatremia tends to present with nausea, headache, malaise, and seizures. In addition, hyponatremia tends to present with non-specific ECG findings. 
❌ Hypoglycemia :
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia can present with altered mental status and stupor; however, hypoglycemia in and of itself is not associated with ECG changes.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath and a cough productive of yellowish sputum. His symptoms began 6 hours ago. Past medical history is notable for asthma and type I diabetes mellitus. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler and takes daily insulin injections. His temperature is 39.5°C (103°F), pulse is 87/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mmHg, and respirations are 10/min. Physical examination reveals a somnolent patient in respiratory distress with audible wheezing, accessory muscle use, and a prolonged expiratory phase. The patient’s blood glucose is 140 mg/dL. A chest x-ray is ordered and is demonstrated below:


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following set of laboratory findings will most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an asthma exacerbation likely secondary to pneumonia (note the consolidation in the apical segments of the left lower lobe). In the early stages of asthma exacerbation, patients develop a respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation (blowing off CO2). Over time, and without treatment, these patients develop signs of respiratory fatigue (e.g., reduced respiratory rate, accessory muscle muscle) and respiratory acidosis secondary to hypoventilation.

The primary driver of respiratory acidosis is CO2 accumulation. Specific causes include airway obstruction (e.g. obstruction by a foreign object), respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., trauma, obesity, fatigue), and alveoli damage (e.g., chronic pulmonary obstructive disease, pulmonary edema). In certain circumstances, hypoventilation occurs secondary to damage or action on the respiratory centers of the brain stem--such as after a stroke or medication overdose (e.g., opioids, sedatives).

Overtime, the body compensates for respiratory acidosis by increasing bicarbonate levels. This phenomenon is termed “respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation” and is mediated via the kidneys via increasing HCO3− reabsorption. This effect, however, takes 24 hours of persistent respiratory acidosis before compensation takes effect. Thus in an acute respiratory acidosis, the pH is low while the HCO3− is normal or slightly elevated. In patients with chronic respiratory acidosis (e.g. COPD or obesity hypoventilation syndrome), the kidneys have time to compensate, resulting in a pH that is closer to normal but with a markedly elevated HCO3−.

 

Option Analysis

✅  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L)  7.30  52  70  25 :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L)  7.30  52  70 35:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. This patient’s asthma exacerbation began less than one day ago, which is not enough time for renal compensation via increasing bicarbonate reuptake.
❌  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L) 7.404090 25 :
Incorrect: These lab values are consistent with those of an asymptomatic individual. In contrast, this patient has signs of abnormal breathing (e.g., reduced respiratory rate, accessory muscle use) secondary to asthma exacerbation.
❌  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L) 7.5025100 25 :
Incorrect: This answer choice is consistent with a respiratory alkalosis, which may be seen early in the clinical course of an asthmatic patient with hyperventilation. However, this patient has signs of respiratory muscle fatigue (e.g., reduced respiratory rate, accessory muscle use, somnolence).
❌  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L) 7.50409030:
Incorrect: These findings demonstrate a metabolic alkalosis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with impending respiratory failure and acidosis secondary to an asthma exacerbation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with suicidal ideation. Today is the fourth day of hospitalization, and the course has been uncomplicated. The patient has been participating in therapy, taking medications, and eating daily. During rounds, the patient is noted to have altered mental status. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 102/74 mmHg, and BMI is 17 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. On physical exam, the patient appears thin and cachectic with several healing lacerations noted over the volar aspect of the wrists. Multiple calluses are present over the knuckles of the right hand. She has 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities bilaterally and faint bibasilar rales on pulmonary auscultation. She is having intermittent convulsions in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is most likely present?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of anorexia nervosa, including a cachectic state, low BMI, and positive Russell sign. The patient develops seizures and congestive heart failure after her nutritional intake is increased during the hospitalization, which raises concerns for refeeding syndrome. Of the listed electrolyte derangements, hypophosphatemia is most commonly seen with this condition.  

 Refeeding syndrome occurs in significantly malnourished patients during the initial stages of oral, enteral, or parenteral nutritional replenishment. The nutrition causes electrolyte and fluid shifts that may precipitate disabling or fatal medical complications including hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, congestive heart failure, peripheral edema, seizures, and hemolysis.  

Hypophosphatemia arises since in the starved state, cellular metabolism slows and blood glucose is low. When feeding is reinstituted, blood glucose increases, driving insulin upwards and shifting phosphate into cells for ATP synthesis, thus leading to hypophosphatemia.  

Other causes of hypophosphatemia include decreased intestinal absorption and increased urinary excretion of phosphate. Decreased intestinal absorption of phosphate can occur due to excess alcohol intake or antacid use. Increased urinary excretion of phosphate occurs due to conditions such as hyperparathyroidism or Fanconi syndrome. 

Acute symptoms of hypophosphatemia occur due to insufficient ATP formation and include metabolic encephalopathy, impaired myocardial contractility, respiratory failure due to weakness of the diaphragm, myopathy, dysphagia, and ileus. Chronically, hypophosphatemia results in weak bones, osteomalacia, and rickets in children.  

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

Option Analysis

✅ Hypophosphatemia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypermagnesemia:
Incorrect: Hypomagnesemia, as opposed to hypermagnesemia, is commonly observed in patients with refeeding syndrome. This phenomenon is due to increased uptake of magnesium from the bloodstream for intracellular processes. 
❌ Hyperchloremia:
Incorrect: Hyperchloremia is not commonly implicated in refeeding syndrome. In contrast, hyperchloremia is often seen in the setting of a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis or when large volumes of crystalloid are infused. 
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: This thin and cachetic patient with signs of self-induced vomiting (e.g. calluses over the knuckles) likely has anorexia nervosa. She developed seizures and congestive heart failure after increasing her nutritional intake during hospitalization, which raises concerns for refeeding syndrome. Refeeding syndrome more commonly presents with hypokalemia, as opposed to hyperkalemia.
❌  Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: This patient has been having good daily nutritional intake since being admitted to the hospital. As a result, it is unlikely she has hypoglycemia.
